org.lazywizard.lazylib.ui

Class LazyFont.DrawableString

  • Object
    • LazyFont.DrawableString
  • Enclosing class:
    LazyFont

    public class LazyFont.DrawableString
extends Object
    Represents an efficiently redrawable block of text. See the documentation for LazyFont for example usage.
    Since:
    2.3
    Author:
    LazyWizard

      • getFont

        public LazyFont getFont()
        Returns a reference to the LazyFont used to create this LazyFont.DrawableString.
        Returns:
        The font used to create this LazyFont.DrawableString.
        Since:
        2.3

      • getWidth

        public float getWidth()
        Returns the width of the rendered text area. This is not the same as getMaxWidth() - this only considers the area used by the text.
        Returns:
        The width of the text area to be rendered.
        Since:
        2.3

      • getHeight

        public float getHeight()
        Returns the height of the rendered text area. This is not the same as getMaxHeight() - this only considers the area used by the text.
        Returns:
        The height of the text area to be rendered.
        Since:
        2.3

      • getFontSize

        public float getFontSize()
        Returns the font size text will be drawn at.
        Returns:
        The font size of this LazyFont.DrawableString.
        Since:
        2.3

      • setFontSize

        public void setFontSize(float fontSize)
        Changes the font size that this text will be rendered at.

        Changing the font size will necessitate a full rebuild of the LazyFont.DrawableString the next time you attempt to draw or measure the text.

        Parameters:
        fontSize - The new font size to render at.
        Since:
        2.3

      • getMaxWidth

        public float getMaxWidth()
        Returns the maximum width of the area that this text will be rendered within.
        Returns:
        The maximum width of the text area. Text will wrapped at the last word that fit within this area.
        Since:
        2.3

      • setMaxWidth

        public void setMaxWidth(float maxWidth)
        Changes the maximum width of the area that this text will be rendered within.

        Changing the text area constraints will necessitate a full rebuild of the LazyFont.DrawableString the next time you attempt to draw or measure the text.

        Parameters:
        maxWidth - The nex maximum width of the text area. Text will be wrapped at the last word that fit within this area.
        Since:
        2.3

      • getMaxHeight

        public float getMaxHeight()
        Returns the maximum height of the area that this text will be rendered within.
        Returns:
        The maximum height of the text area. Further text will be discarded once this limit is reached.
        Since:
        2.3

      • setMaxHeight

        public void setMaxHeight(float maxHeight)
        Changes the maximum height of the area that this text will be rendered within.

        Changing the text area constraints will necessitate a full rebuild of the LazyFont.DrawableString the next time you attempt to draw or measure the text.

        Parameters:
        maxHeight - The nex maximum height of the text area. Further text will be discarded once this limit is reached.
        Since:
        2.3

      • getColor

        public Color getColor()
        Returns the current color text will be drawn as.
        Returns:
        The color text will be drawn as.
        Since:
        2.3

      • setColor

        public void setColor(Color color)
        Sets the color text will be drawn as.

        Unlike most setX() methods in this class, calling this will not trigger a rebuild of the entire LazyFont.DrawableString.

        Parameters:
        color - The color to draw the text as.
        Since:
        2.3

      • getText

        public String getText()
        Returns the raw text of this LazyFont.DrawableString, before any word-wrapping is applied. Performance note: due to the underlying text being stored in a StringBuilder, a new String will be built every time this method is called.
        Returns:
        The raw text of this LazyFont.DrawableString (without word-wrapping applied).
        Since:
        2.3
        See Also:
        to calculate the text after wrapping is applied.

      • setText

        public void setText(String text)
        Replaces all text in the LazyFont.DrawableString with the entered String.

        Changing a LazyFont.DrawableString's text will necessitate a full rebuild of its contents the next time you attempt to draw or measure the text.

        Parameters:
        text - The String to set this LazyFont.DrawableString's contents to.
        Since:
        2.3

      • appendText

        public void appendText(String text)
        Adds additional text to the end of the current text.

        Changing a LazyFont.DrawableString's text will necessitate a full rebuild of its contents the next time you attempt to draw or measure the text.

        Parameters:
        text - The text to add to the LazyFont.DrawableString.
        Since:
        2.3

      • appendText

        public void appendText(String text,
                       Color color)
        Adds a colored substring to the end of the current text. Only this substring will use the given color, and all further normally appended text will use the color returned by getColor().

        Changing a LazyFont.DrawableString's text will necessitate a full rebuild of its contents the next time you attempt to draw or measure the text.

        Parameters:
        text - The text to add to the LazyFont.DrawableString.
        color - The color this text should appear as.
        Since:
        2.5c

      • appendText

        public void appendText(String text,
                       int indent)
        Adds additional text to the end of the current text.

        Changing a LazyFont.DrawableString's text will necessitate a full rebuild of its contents the next time you attempt to draw or measure the text.

        Parameters:
        text - The text to add to the LazyFont.DrawableString.
        indent - All lines will be prepended with this number of blank spaces.
        Since:
        2.3

      • appendText

        public void appendText(String text,
                       Color color,
                       int indent)
        Adds a colored substring to the end of the current text. Only this substring will use the given color, and all further normally appended text will use the color returned by getColor().

        Changing a LazyFont.DrawableString's text will necessitate a full rebuild of its contents the next time you attempt to draw or measure the text.

        Parameters:
        text - The text to add to the LazyFont.DrawableString.
        indent - All lines will be prepended with this number of blank spaces.
        color - The color this text should appear as.
        Since:
        2.5c

      • draw

        public void draw(float x,
                 float y)
        Renders the text area at the specified coordinates. This method must be called once per frame.

        You can render the same block of text in multiple places. The OpenGL commands are cached in a display list, so performance should not be an issue (provided the underlying data isn't changed, necessitating a rebuild).

        Parameters:
        x - The X coordinate to draw at.
        y - The Y coordinate to draw at.
        Since:
        2.3

      • draw

        public void draw(Vector2f location)
        Renders the text area at the specified coordinates. This method must be called once per frame.

        You can render the same block of text in multiple places. The OpenGL commands are cached in a display list, so performance should not be an issue (provided the underlying data isn't changed, necessitating a rebuild).

        Parameters:
        location - The coordinates to draw at.
        Since:
        2.3

      • drawAtAngle

        public void drawAtAngle(float x,
                        float y,
                        float angle)
        Renders the text area at the specified coordinates with the specified angle. This method must be called once per frame.

        You can render the same block of text in multiple places. The OpenGL commands are cached in a display list, so performance should not be an issue (provided the underlying data isn't changed, necessitating a rebuild).

        Parameters:
        x - The X coordinate to draw at.
        y - The Y coordinate to draw at.
        angle - The angle to draw at.
        Since:
        2.3

      • drawAtAngle

        public void drawAtAngle(Vector2f location,
                        float angle)
        Renders the text area at the specified coordinates with the specified angle. This method must be called once per frame.

        You can render the same block of text in multiple places. The OpenGL commands are cached in a display list, so performance should not be an issue (provided the underlying data isn't changed, necessitating a rebuild).

        Parameters:
        location - The coordinates to draw at.
        angle - The angle to draw at.
        Since:
        2.3

      • isDisposed

        public boolean isDisposed()
        Whether this object's underlying OpenGL resources have been cleaned up - attempting to render after disposal will cause a RuntimeException!
        Returns:
        true if dispose() has been called; false otherwise.
        Since:
        2.3

      • dispose

        public void dispose()
        Cleans up the underlying OpenGL resources of this LazyFont.DrawableString. Calling any draw() method after this will cause a RuntimeException.

        Calling this method is optional, and rarely required. However, there are a limited number of display lists available, so if you are creating many thousands of LazyFont.DrawableStrings, you will need to call this when done with each to prevent the pool from being exhausted before the garbage collector can get around to cleaning them up for you.

        Since:
        2.3
